H0.text: A moon would be best seen through a telescope.

H1.text: A cell is the best seen through a telescope.

H2.text: A light ray is best seen through a telescope.

H3.text: A molecule is best seen through a telescope.

A4.text: The first record of telescopic astronomy and rough mapping of the Moon's features is from early summer 1609 by Thomas Harriot, but which he did not publish.

A5.text: At the same time Galileo Galilei too started to use telescopes to observe the sky and the Moon, recording later that year more detailed observations and crucial conclusions, such as that the Moon was not smooth, featuring mountains and craters, which he published in 1610 in his ground-breaking and soon widely discussed book Sidereus Nuncius.
